description: From Middle English rowel, rowell, rowelle, from Old French roel, roiele (compare modern French rouelle), from Late Latin rotella, diminutive of Latin rota (“wheel”). Doublet of rotella.

entries.meaning: The small spiked wheel on the end of a spur.
examples: The deep and sharp rowels with which Ivanhoe’s heels were now armed, began to make the worthy Prior repent of his courtesy, […] .

entries.meaning: A little flat ring or wheel on a horse's bit.
examples: The iron rowels into frothy foam he bit.

entries.meaning: A roll of hair, silk, etc., passed through the flesh of a horse in the manner of a seton in human surgery.

verbs.description: rowel (third-person singular simple present rowels, present participle roweling or rowelling, simple past and past participle roweled or rowelled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To use a rowel on (something), especially to drain fluid.

examples: He would have been completely ignorant of what was going on if Frank, periodically roweled by the viciously anti-labor stand of the Pittsburgh newspapers, hadn't felt the need of an audience.
